column45: The LERC Wales mobile application enables you to get involved in biological recording in Wales. You can contribute your sightings with photos, GPS acquired coordinates, descriptions and other information, thus providing scientists with important new biodiversity information that contributes to nature conservation, planning, research and education.
column47: We encourage everyone to get involved with recording species as it is very easy and quick to submit useful records without specialist knowledge. It doesn't matter whether you are an amateur enthusiast or a qualified biologist, the LERC Wales app is for anyone who wants to contribute to our database observations of the natural environment
column49: This app was developed by the BRC mobile development team on behalf of the Local Environmental Record Centres in Wales. For suggestions and feedback please do not hesitate to
column52: The Local Environmental Records Centres Wales
column53: is a consortium made up of the four Records Centres in Wales
column54: We work closely together to provide a seamless service for the data users in Wales and to support the voluntary recording community across the principality
column55: How to make a new record
column56: There are two ways to start a record
column59: in the home page header. This will prompt you to select the photo source: camera or gallery. Once you have picked a photo, the app will create a new record without any species associated with it. Clicking on the newly created record will open the taxa search page.
column62: button in the home page header. This will bring you to the taxa search page. After selecting the species, open the record (either by opening it directly from the taxa search page using the edit button
column63: beside the species name or through the home-list page) and fill in the details of the sighting, like location, date, number seen etc
column64: When finished, set for submission by pressing the paper plane
column67: The application holds all of the UK’s species (70000+) and all the associated taxonomy ranks. For quicker searching of the taxa you can use different shortcuts. For example, to find
column68: you can type in the search bar
column70: All your saved records will be shown on the home page. By default a record is in
column72: mode until it is set for submission. While it is in
column73: mode the application will not synchronise your record with the database. To set it for sending, open the record and press the
column74: button in the header. The application will try to submit your record once there is a good network connection
column75: If the record has reached the database a red
column77: Once it has successfully reached the database the record becomes unavailable for new edits. To further edit it please use the
column80: you have to be signed in to your iRecord account and have a network connection, for the records to be automatically synchronised in the background
column82: You can set all your draft records for submission. To do that go to the settings page
column84: This will try to send all the valid records
column86: To delete a record, swipe it left in the home-list page and click the delete
column87: You can also remove all the locally saved records that have been successfully synchronised with the database. This will leave the records on the database untouched. To do that go to settings page
column90: You can lock record attributes like date, location, number etc, which will preserve your current attribute value for the subsequently added records
column91: To lock an attribute click on the lock
column92: button in the attribute edit page header. This will change the symbol to locked
column93: both on the button and next to the attribute
column94: For a GPS-sourced location, only the location name can be locked, not the GPS value. As you move about, the GPS value will change. This will allow recording of different GPS values within an named area while keeping the location name the same. You can lock a location if it is selected using a map or entered manually

column120: Wherever you see this logo on a biological recording app you can be assured that the data you submit will be: made available to experts for quality assurance; made available for conservation and research and preserved for long-term use.
column121: This logo indicates that your data is
column122: Sent to the Biological Record Centre’s data warehouse linked to the iRecord system where it accessible to you as the recorder, to an expert community of verifiers and other users of iRecord
column123: Quality assured data is passed onto Local Environmental Records Centres, National Recording Schemes and to the NBN Gateway
column125: established in 1964, is a national focus in the UK for terrestrial and freshwater species recording. BRC works closely with the voluntary recording community, principally through support of national recording schemes and societies. BRC is supported by the Joint Nature Conservation Committee (JNCC) and the Centre for Ecology & Hydrology (CEH) within the Natural Environment Research Council (NERC). The work of BRC is a major component of the National Biodiversity Network (NBN)
column127: You might have noticed that several of
column129: feature some of the same species?  We have introduced the BRC Approved logo to signify that data from our apps all go to the same place. Therefore, you are free to choose which app you use to record a given species. All records will be sent to the same place, treated in the same way and will meet the established standards required by the Biological Record Centre

column123: Mae data y mae eu hansawdd wedi'i sicrhau'n cael eu hanfon ymlaen i'r Canolfannau Cofnodion Amgylcheddol Lleol, i'r Cynlluniau Cofnodi Cenedlaethol ac i Borth NBN
column125: Wedi'i sefydlu yn 1964, mae'n ffocws cenedlaethol yn y DU ar gyfer cofnodi rhywogaethau tir a dŵr croyw. Mae BRC yn gweithio'n agos â'r gymuned gofnodi wirfoddol, yn bennaf drwy gefnogi cynlluniau a chymdeithasau cofnodi cenedlaethol. Cefnogir BRC gan y Cydbwyllgor Cadwraeth Natur (JNCC) a'r Ganolfan ar gyfer Ecoleg a Hydroleg (CEH) yn y Cyngor Ymchwil ar gyfer yr Amgylchedd Naturiol (NERC). Mae gwaith BRC yn elfen bwysig o'r Rhwydwaith Bioamrywiaeth Cenedlaethol (NBN)

Anfonir pob cofnod i'r un lle, byddant yn cael eu trin yr un fath ac yn bodloni'r safonau wedi'u sefydlu sy'n ofynnol gan y Ganolfan Cofnodion Biolegol.
